meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! I'm back at it again, dishing out my signature blend of humor and game review goodness!

This time, I've got my eyes on Astor: Blade of the Monolith, an action RPG that's got me swinging my sword in anticipation. But before we dive into the good stuff, let me tell you – I'm not here to sugarcoat things. I'll give you the lowdown, the highs and lows (pun intended), and maybe even a few snarky comments about those other critics who had the pleasure of playing this game.

First off, SpazioGames says it's "decent" with a score of 70. Decent? That's like saying I'm decent at making dad jokes – it's okay, but let's not get too excited. Meanwhile, God is a Geek gives it a 65 and calls it "enjoyable" once you unlock some sweet new moves. I mean, who doesn't love leveling up?

Shacknews chimes in with a score of 70, saying Astor: Blade of the Monolith does what all good games should do – take familiar concepts and make them feel fresh again. They also mention that the combat is "niche" but not quite perfect. Yeah, I'd say it's like trying to hit a bullseye blindfolded while doing a backflip – you can try, but it might not end well.

Now, RPGamer is having none of this, giving Astor: Blade of the Monolith a paltry 40. They claim it feels like a game that needed more cooking time – and honestly, I agree. The gameplay's undercooked, there are bugs galore, and the plot? Well, let's just say it could've used some major rewrites.

Last but not least, GameSkinny gives it a 60, saying it's an "evocative" and "charming" hack-and-slash adventure with plenty of great ideas. Yeah, I can dig that – but hey, execution is key, right?

So what does all this mean? Well, for me, it means one thing: Astor: Blade of the Monolith is a mixed bag. It's got some awesome ideas, but needs a little more polish to really shine. That said, if you're an action RPG fan looking for something new and exciting (with a bit of patience), this might be just the ticket.

And there you have it – my two cents on Astor: Blade of the Monolith! What do you think? Did I hit the mark or miss by a mile? Let me know in the comments!
